instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
No water damage, this board was not powering up because it had <SIGNAL>PP0V9_TBT_X_SVR</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL> shorted to ground.
Removed <RESISTOR>R5640</RESISTOR> to isolate <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and board powered on fine and charged great but obviously no usb Data or HDMI output.

I replaced <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> with a preballed one and put back <RESISTOR>R5640</RESISTOR>, I have no more shorts but still no hdmi output and no usb data.  In the EFI boot menu I can see my external usb drive...

I am thinking to grab a <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> from a donnour board and reball it  (got finally the stencil). Thought maybe these chip come with some firmware...

Is there anything else I can check before I replace the chip with an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> donnour one?

Thanks

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
If you can see external disk on boot menu, can you start from it?
Under macOS, did you check both USB2/3 modes?
The USB-C redriver chip looks good?

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
No I can't start from the external disk on boot menu.  When I start an external disk OS I see the apple logo with the progress bar at let say 60% and I get the Apple prohibitory sign, tested with different volumes (Catalina, High Sierra and Mojave) they all finish with the prohibitory sign. I tried also to load external macOs with a 2.0 and 3.0 USB drive and same thing.

Yes under Macos with internal ssd I tried both USB 2.0 and 3.0 no one show up on the desktop, checked also in disk utility no disk is detected.

For the redriver USB-C chip: if you are talking about the PI3USB3224BXEAE ic that doesn't exist on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view I have visually nothing to say about it.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
You've said to have 00840 board.
That chip doesn't appear on schematic, nor boardview; but is present on the board.

USB mouse is working?

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
Yes i have 00840 board with the chip present and it looks good.  And am using the 00875 schematic and boardview on witch the chip doesn’t appear.

USB mouse is working only on the boot menu same as the detected external usb boot drives.
When the MacOS is launched the usb mouse is disabled.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
Then you have problem with SPI mode of trackpad.
Check diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI</SIGNAL> lines; may have a protection diode damaged.
Also check the pull-up resistors, page 16.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
I’ve  just compared diode mode values for <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI</SIGNAL> lines with known working board and they are the same.

Pull-up resistors related to tpad on page 16 are all within specs according to values shown on schematic.

Should I replace again <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> or that has nothing to do with HDMI/usb disabled on spi mode?

thanks

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> has nothing to do with TP-PCH communication.
Check <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_CS_CONN_L</SIGNAL> voltage; logged into macOS, with TP connected, of course.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
I soldered a wire from J4801-pin 13 and I am measuring 3.3V on  <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_CS_CONN_L</SIGNAL> with trackpad connected while logged in macOS.
Just in case I tested with another set of trackpad and flex cable and I have the same results.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
Sorry man, I just saw your problem is with USB mouse, not internal.

Something happens when macOS start to load the drivers.
That explain the prohibited sign; because system lose communication with external disk.
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> may affect the communication.

Check starting in Diagnostic mode is any error pops up.

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
Oh no problem at all.

I was able to simulate the same issue with a known working board by  preventing <SIGNAL>PP0V9_TBT_X_SVR</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL>  to feed <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, I had the exact issue. Suprisingly nothing is reported in diagnostic mode.

So I just reballed an another <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> from a donnor board and problem is solved now!
The preballed chip I had was either bad or just bad reballing, found it more difficult than Gmux on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>!

Thanks for your support!

threads.title: SOLVED - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> shorted <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>
threads.message:
Thanks for feedback.
This can save time for other forum members, in the future.
